DIV1.P: DER MITTELENGLISCHE VERSROMAN ÜBER RICHARD LÖWENHERZ
KRITISCHE AUSGABE NACH ALLEN HANDSCHRIFTEN MIT EINLEITUNG, ANMERKUNGEN UND DEUTSCHER ÜBERSETZUNG VON KARL BRUNNER DR. PHIL. (INNSBRUCK).
WIEN UND LEIPZIG WILHELM BRAUMÜLLER K. U. K. HOF- UND UNIVERSITÄTS-BUCHHÄNDLER 1913
II. TEXT MIT VARIANTEN ALLER HANDSCHRIFTEN.

DIV1.HEAD: Einrichtung der Ausgabe.
DIV1.P: An erster Stelle steht der Text der Fassung a mit C oder, soweit dieses lückenhaft ist, mit W als Grundlage. Von b wurden nur die abweichenden Textstellen, und zwar unter dem Striche kursiv abgedruckt. Hier bildet, soweit dies möglich ist, A die Grundlage des Textes.

Die Varianten bieten alle abweichenden Lesarten der übrigen Hss., mit Ausschluß rein orthographischer Ver∣schiedenheiten, wie Wechsel zwischen i und y; i und j; ai, ei, ay, ey untereinander; c und k vor a, o, u; c und s vor e und i; gh und ȝ; ff und f im Wortanlaut und in of, off; sch und sh; þ und th; e und i in Endungssilben. Da es sich um späte Hss. handelt, konnte auch das von den einzelnen Schreibern willkürlich gehandhabte Schreiben oder Nicht∣schreiben eines End-e und die verschiedene Art der Be∣zeichnung oder Nichtbezeichnung der Vokallänge durch Doppelschreiben, Stellung in offener Silbe oder auch in geschlossener vor einfachem Konsonanten vernachlässigt werden. Außerdem wurden folgende orthographische Eigen∣tümlichkeiten einzelner Hss. nur einmal hervorgehoben und dann nicht mehr beachtet:

LIST.ITEM: Acris B D H E für Acres
baroun B H γ für baron
broghte A B, browt D für brought und untereinander
bytwene BW β E für betwene
dromonde D H W für dromounde, drowmounde
dromounde A B für dromonde, drowmounde
Griffoun B L H für Griffon
hem DHLEA, þam B,themW, theym B für hem und untereinander
here B β E, hure A, their BW hir B für her und untereinander
i D H für ich oder ic
ich L A, ic A für i
knyt D, knyth D für knight
messenger E W, messanger B H, messager A, massenger D für messanger und untereinander
nowt D für nouȝt oder noghte
pauylyoun B, pauelyoun B, paue∣loune H, pauylone D E für pauy∣loun und untereinander
sance B, sanz A, sam δ für saunce und untereinander
Sarazenes A B, Saracenus A, Sary∣zyns E, Sarazynes B H D, Sara∣synes W, Sarrasins L für Sary∣cenes und untereinander
Soudan L E β BW, Soudon A D für Saudon und untereinander
styward H D A für steward
suche W A E, soche H, swiche L für swilk und untereinander
yt D, itte H für hit

DIV1.P: Die Orthographie der Varianten ist die der zuerst ge∣nannten Hs., beziehungweise für a die von C, für b die von A, für α (= C B) die von C, für β (= A H) die von A, für γ (= L D E) die von L, für δ (= E D) die von E. Die Verwen∣dung der großen und kleinen Anfangsbuchstaben und der Interpunktionszeichen wurde nach dem heutigen Gebrauche geregelt. Die Haken über manchen Buchstaben (n, r) oder die Schwänze nach t wurden im allgemeinen als e aufgelöst, Haken über n in der flexivischen Endung-en in B D jedoch nicht beachtet.

DIV2.HEAD: Abkürzungen:
DIV2.P: f. = fehlt; α = C B; β = A H; γ = L D E; δ = E D; b = alle Hss. der Fassung b, in denen die betreffende Stelle überliefert ist.

And a spere to hym he bare, D statt 290-318:
On his schelde a dynte he sette
That top ouer tayl to grounde he ȝede,
Ffor al þe strenthe of his stede.
Bothe hors and man he fel to gronde,
Wel ny he hadde his dedes wonde.
Anoder knyth, hardy and goode,
Vpon a stede rede so blode,
He dede hym arme wel þat tyde,
And thowte ageyne þe kyng to ryde.
A goode spere on hende he bare,
Kynge Ric. of hyme was ware.
In to þe ffelde he thowte to ryde
Ageyne þat knyte wiþ mekyl pride.

With queyntyse and with strength of honde, 1846 W. cointyse a. D, W. queynt∣nesse a. W2, f. H ‖ w. strenthe of h. D, W. the st. of owre h. H, w. craftis mo B.

Of the Frensshe and of the Gryffons 1847 Of F. W, On þe Frenchemen D, On Ffrensche∣menne H, One the Fraunche men B ‖ of G. W, of þe Griffouns L, one þe Griffounes B, on þe Grefone D, the Gryffounes H.
That haue dyspysed our nacyons. 1848 hath D A. hase thus B ‖ disspysed B D, despised L ‖ nacyouns B L H, nacouns A, nacyone D.
I haue a castell, i vnderstonde, 1849 Ich u. ö. L A ‖ vndirstande B.
Was made of tembre of Englonde, 1850 Is m. W, That w. m. β, Mad D, Of timber L ‖ of tymber H B D, of tymbre A, made L ‖ of Ing∣lond L, of Ingelonde D, of Ynglande B, in Engelonde A, jn Englonde H.
With syxe stages full of tourelles 1851 sex L D H, sere B ‖ f. of torells B, ful of turels L, and tureles D, imade of stirells β.

Well flourysshed with cornelles; 1852 Wele yflorist L, Wel iflurshed A, Welle yfflorysched H, Ffull wele floreste B, Wel idyth D ‖ w. kirnels L, w. many kirnells B, w. gode kernells A, w. gode kervelles H, wiþowtyn les D.
Therin i and many a knyght 1853 þer j and B, Therin shall be β ‖ many an other knyghte B, many a doughty knyght A.

Ayenst the Frensshe shall take the fyght. 1854 Agaynes B, Oȝeyn L, Ageyne D, Aȝeyne H ‖ þe Ffraunce me B, the Ffrenschemenne H, þe Grifouns D ‖ sall t. þe f. B, wolde take þe fyth D, wil held f. L, to holde þe f. A, for fyght H.
That castell shall haue a surnom, 1855 The castell B β, My castel DL ‖ sall highte B ‖ a surnum A, a surnownne B, a sornoun L, a sirename D, a surname H, a sory nom W.
It shall hyght the Mate-Gryffon. 1856 He shall β, For it sall B ‖ hote β, hattyn D, hat B, be hoten L ‖ þe M. Griffoun L, Matte Griffoun B, Mat de Grifone D, Mau de Griffoun A, Mawnge Gryffoune H.
Maryners, arme wele your shyppes, 1857 beginnt E; Now m. LD, unleserlich E, My m. B ‖ a. well β, armi w. L, arme DW, un∣deutlich E, lukes ȝe arme wele B ‖ sh. blyue E, sch. swythe D.
And holde vp your manshyppes, 1858 holdeþ vp L, h. vp wele A, haldis vp wele B, do up W, ȝour strenthe D ‖ our m. L, oure manchippys B, one þe Grifone kythe D, nur k. leserlich E.
By the water-halfe ye them assayle, 1859 And bi L, And ye by β, Jn D ‖ the] f. H ‖ h.] f. Bβ ‖ ȝe hem aseyl LD, ȝe schall þame a. B, shall hem a. β.
And we by the londe saunce fayle; 1860 A. i shall D, A. we wyll W ‖ be þe l. D, bi þe lande B, by l. WH, in þe l. half wil L ‖ samfayle D, samfaille A, wiþouten f. LH.
For joye come neuer to me 1861 F. j. cometh H, F. certis j. commys B, J. ne comeþ þer L, J. comyth D, F. come ye W ‖ n. vnto me HB, n. non to me D.
Tyll i of them awrecked be!" 1862 Or j of DH, Or ich on A, Or þat j B ‖ them] hem u. ö. LAD, f. B ‖ awreken L, awroke A, avenged B.
Therto men myght here crye: 1863 Þo L, Þat nyth D ‖ m. m. h.] men herdyn D, dide ilke a man B ‖ ycrie L, gret c. D, to cry B.
"Helpe God and Saynt Mary!" 1863 und 1864 fehlen β. 1864 A help L, Helpe now D.
The maryners them gan hye, 1865 Bot than the maryners B ‖ theym gane B, hem gun L, gunne hem D, gan to W, swithe on A, faste on H ‖ heyȝe L, heye D, hyghe H.
Bothe with shyppe and with galye, 1866 Bothe with schippes BL, Greythed shippes A, Made al redy bothe schyppe H ‖ w. galeyȝe L, w. galey D, galie β.
With ore, spredde, and sayle also 1867 W. are and sprete B, W. o. and seyl LD, Syth o. s. W, W. bowsprete β ‖ a. spere also L, spret also D, a. s. blyve β.
Towarde the cite they gan go. 1868 T. the cete D, Vnto the c. H, Jnto the c.A, And to þe c.B, T. them W ‖ þai gun go LD, þane gane they go B, ganne þey dryve H, they gon to dryue A.
The knyghtes framed the tre-castell 1869 þe knytes D, Knyghtes β, The wrightis B ‖ þane f. B, streynyd D ‖ þat t. castel L, the t. castyll W.
Before the cyte vpon an hyll. 1870 Bifor L, Besyde H, Al on A ‖ cete u. ö. D ‖ appone B, on LDH ‖ hel L, hil D.
All this sawe the Kynge of Fraunce, 1871 þis yseyȝe L, That hym s. A, That hym sawgh H, And that it sees B, Fful oftyn tyme D ‖ of] f.W.
And sayd: "Haue ye no doutaunce 1872 Seyde D, Lordynges, he seide A ‖ no h. ȝe L ‖ no dowtance B, no dotaunce L, non dotaunce A, no distance D.
Of all these Englyssh cowardes, 1873 O. a. thies B, Of thes β, Of the LD ‖ Inglische u. ö. L ‖ tay∣lardes βD.
For they ne be but mossardes; 1874 F. th. be H, F. þ. no be L, Hij ne buth A, Ffor þay ne are noghtis B ‖ bot BL ‖ mosardes A, cowardes DH, losardes W.

Drisses now your mangenell, 1875 Do drisses n. B, Ordeyne n. D, Dighteth he seide A, Dyght he seyde H, But reyse vp W1, But ryse vp W2 ‖ ȝ.] owre H ‖ mawn∣gonelle B, mangunel L, mawngevelle H, magnel D, mangenelles A.
And caste to theyr tre-castell, 1876 castith D, castis B, kestes L, sett hym H ‖ to her t. c. L, to here treyn c. D, into the t. c. B, to the t. c. H, towarde your t. c. A.
And shote to them with arblast, 1877 schete Dβ, scheteþ L, schottis B ‖ at þam B ‖ alblast LDB.
The tayled dogges for to agast!" 1878 t. doggen L, tayle d. A, dogge-tayles H ‖ for] f. BLD ‖ to make a. D.
Now harken of Rycharde, our kynge, 1879 N. herkneþ of L, Bot herkyns now of B, Thanne D, Sone after β ‖ R. þat was oure k. D.
How he let bere in the dawnynge 1880 . . . (verwischt) hadde do born L, Dede bere D, Lette bere H, Let bere A ‖ dawnnynge B, daweing L, dawenyng H.
Targes and hurdis his folke all 1881 T. a. hurdas B, Terges a. hardes W, T. and dores β, Torches bordes and D ‖ to his folkes alle B, his men all D.
Right before the cyte-wall. 1882 bifore u. ö. BL, aforne A, afore H ‖ þe toun w.D.
His hoost he let at ones crye—1883 H. ost he dede at o. c. L, H. hoste att ones he lette c. H, H. oste at onys he dud c. A, Anone he dede his ost to c. D, And his folke he garte at anes c. B.
Men myght it here into the skye—1884 xxat mene Bβ ‖ it here LH, yt heryn D, hem hure A, hafe harde B ‖ in W, to H.

"Now let come the Frenssh mosardes, 1885 Now lassee cum L, Late see come forthe B, Now come on D, And seyde H, They seide: Let se A ‖ þe F. misardes D, thou Fraunce moserde B, F. mosardes A, F. musardes L, ȝe F. mosardes H, the F. losardes W.
And gyue batayll to the taylardes!" 1886 A. ȝif bateyl L, A. gyf batail D, A. giffe b. B, Come now yeve b. A, Cometh to ffyghte H ‖ to þe Englysshe t. D, to þe Ynglys tailerde B, wiþ þe t. H.
Þe Fresshemen them armed all, 1887 þe F. folk L D, Bot than the Fraunce-mene B ‖ a. th. a. B D, sone armed hem a. H, anon a. þ. a. A.
And ranne on hast vpon the wall; 1888 A.] Anon A ‖ rane B, vrn L, comyn D, ȝede vppe H, þey yeve A ‖ in h. B, on fast W, anon L, f. β ‖ vnto þe w. L A, to þe w. D, into the w. H.

And gun defende, þe Englysshe for to assayle: 1889 Þai g. defendi and L, A. gan hem defende A, A. faste defendide B, A. faste D, A. ther byganne H, A. began W ‖ þe Y. a. B, þe J. aseyl L, oure Englissh to asail A, hem to assayll D, wiþowte fayle H.

Frenssh and Gryffons fast they slowe. 1892 Þe F. a. þe L β, The F. a. D, And many Franche mene and B ‖ Griffouns u. ö. B L H, Grefons u. ö. D ‖ f. þ. slouȝ A. felde and slowe W, fellyd and fl . . . (abgeschnitten) D, þay slewe B, slowe H.
The galeys came to the cyte, 1893 Þe g. come thane B, Wiþ þat þe g. com L, Wiþ þat comyth þe g. D, Than were the shippes comyn A, By thanne comen schyppes H ‖ to] vnto W.
And had nygh wonne entre. 1894 And allmost h. β ‖ neyȝe L, ny D, nerhande B, f. β ‖ wounnyn D.
They hadde so myned vnder the wall, 1895 Th. h. so] They h. ny D, So harde they β, And harde W ‖ mynned D, moyned H.
That many Gryffons gan downe fall; 1896 Þ. full m. G. B, þat mani a Griffoun L D A, Þ. þe G. H ‖ doune gane f. B, came d. f. D, dydde d. f. H, adoune þer fall A.
With hoked arowes and quarelles 1897 howked H ‖ aruwes L, harwes H, harneys A ‖ a. eke W, a wiþ δ ‖ quarels L, quarell D.

They felle out of the tourelles, 1898 Fele fel L, Many þei feldyn D, Mony fel E, Many ther ful A, Many fylle H, Helde them W ‖ out] doune thikke B, f. H ‖ of þe turels L, of the torells E, of þe torell D, of the tyrells A, of heghe torells B, on the torelles H.
And brake bothe legges, and arme, 1899 brakyn D, breke E, broken L ‖ bothe] bakkes B ‖ legge A D, nekke H ‖ armes W, unleserlich E.

And eke theyr neckes: it was none harme. 1900 A. h. n. L, A. e. her nek A, And also þ. n. B, A. sum þe neke E, A. sume here nekke D, Butte ywysse H ‖ it w. na h. B, þat w. n. h. L, hit w. non h. A, it w. no h. D H, it w. n. harmes W.
The Frensshmen came to the stoure, 1901 The Franche mene come B, The F. com E, The F. keme D, The Freyns com L, Then com Ffrenshmen β ‖ into þe st. B, to her sour L, in þat st. β, to socour δ.
And caste wylde fyre out of the toure; 1902 keste B D, shot β ‖ wilde fuyre β, wyld fere D ‖ oute] f. H ‖ of the heghe t. B, to oure boure D.
Therwith i wote, forsothe, iwys, 1903 Wherwith i. w. W, And þerwith i. w. B, I woot certeyn E, I wot serteyne D, Y wot forsoþe L ‖ f.] welle H, þerwiþ L.
They brent and slew many Englysshe. 1904 brynte a. s. B, b. and slouȝ L, brennyd and slawyn D, slow and brent A, kyllede H ‖ moony E.
And the Englysshmen defended them wele 1905 Ac þe Inglische L, But oure Englissh A, Butt Englysche menne H, The E. δ B ‖ hem defended L, fendyd hem D ‖ w.] f. H.
With good swerdes of browne stele, 1906 W. full gud s. B, W. g. swerde L, W. her s. H ‖ of b. stiel L, of b. stiell A, made of stele B D.
And slewe of them so grete chepes, 1907 A. slough β, A. slouȝen L, A. slow E, They slowyn D ‖ so gret ch. (ch. auf Rasur) L, g. ch. β, wiþ good snepys D.

That there laye moche folke on hepes; 1908 Þ. þ. l. michel f. L, Þ. þ. of heme lay D, Þ. of h . . . (unleserlich) E, That many of hem ther lay A, Th. many ther leye H, Þ. many of þame lay B ‖ on] to L, gret D.
And at the londe-gate Kynge Rycharde 1909 And at þe ȝate D, At londe yate β, And one the lande helde B ‖ þe K. R. L, K. R. stode A.
Helde his assawte ylyke harde, 1910 Held his saut L β, H. þe a. E, Helde asauȝte D, His a. B ‖ yliche L, like W, ay y. B, euere alyche D, euerlich A, euer H.
And so manly he toke one, 1911 A.] f. β ‖ manliche L β, manfully B ‖ he tok on L D, he towke on H, þane toke he one B.

He loste of his men neuer one. 1912 He lefte W, þat he no les L, Þat he . . . (unleserlich) E, That he les D, Thatt he ne leste H, That he ne lafte A, Þat of alle his men loste he B ‖ of h. m. non L, noghte one B, but fewe men D, butte fewe abowne H.
He loked besyde, and sawe houe 1913 He l. biside him L, Þan loked he b. B, Than saugh K. R. A, Kyng Richard sighe H ‖ a. s. one h. B, a. s. in hey D, byside hym houe β.
A knyght that weued hym with a gloue. 1914 that tolde h. W, þat wayvede B, þat tollid hym β, hem to . . . (unleserlich) E, hym clepide D ‖ w. g. A, w. glory D.
Kynge Rycharde come, and he hym tolde 1915 K. R. came a. D, K. R. a. W, When he come to him A ‖ he h. talde B, hyme told D.

Tales in Englyssh, stoute and bolde: 1915 und 1916 fehlen H. 1916 Tales on Inglis L, Tak jn E. D, Take of þe . . . (unleserlich) E, Tuk of E. A, Takes Ynglys wiþ ȝow he seid B ‖ s. a. balde B, gode a. b. D.

"A lorde, i haue aspyed now ryght 1917 For lo, Sir, i hafe asspyed B, A lorde he sayd, i aspye W, A Richard, ich aspied L, A Ric. i haue spiyd D, And seide: Sir, ich haue aspied A, He seyde, he had spyedde H ‖ now ryght] a sight β.
A thinge that maketh myn herte lyght. 1918 þyng þ. L, That β ‖ makes B, made H ‖ my hert A D, ys herte H ‖ now l. B, ful lyth D, somdele l. H.
Here", he sayd, "is a gate one 1919 H. vp, Sir is β, Her vp ich fond L D, He besyde es B ‖ a yate on A, gate on L, yate on H, a ȝate vndon D.
That hath warde ryght none. 1920 Þ. no haue ward non L, Þ. ne hath warde none D, Þ. wardeynes in it es neuer one B, Ffor sothe hit haþ warde non β.
The folke is gone to the water-toure 1921 Þe folk is vrn L, Þe folkes are roune B, The menne ar goon H, They be gone D ‖ to þe ȝates of þe toure D.
For to do them there socoure, 1922 don L ‖ hem u. ö. E, ther menne H ‖ there] theyr W, f. D H.
And there we may withouten dente 1923 A.] f. b ‖ we mowe D, we mowe A, ȝe mowghe H ‖ without d. W A, wiþowtten dynt B, w. dynt D, veramente H.
Entre in now, veramente." 1924 Entri in L, Entire in B, Haue entre β ‖ n. verramente B, verrament L, wele v. D, inow v. A, wythowten dynt H.
Blythe therof was Kynge Rycharde, 1925 þane b. th. B, . . . hile was (Anfang weggeschnitten) D, Ffull glad β ‖ the K. D.
Stoutly he wente thederwarde, 1926 And stouteliche priked þiderward L, And hastely wente he th. B, And manliche wente þ. A, And wente manlyche thyderwarde H, And heyide hym faste þo hedyrwarde D.
Many a knyght, doughty of dede, 1927 A. many a k. B β, Wel m. a k. D, Wel m. k. L ‖ duthi L, dowty D.
After hym prycked vpon theyr stede. 1928 A. h. prekede BD, A. h. priked L, A. p. W, Priked after β ‖ appon B, on LDH
Kynge Rycharde entred without drede, 1929 K. R. than e. B, The kyng e. HD ‖ wiþoutyn D β, wiþowtten B.
Hym folowed full grete felawrede. 1930 And ther h. f. B, And wiþ hym D, Wyth alle H ‖ a g. f. B, a fayr felarede D, swythe g. f. A, ys fayre f. H, f. g. ferhede W.
His baner vpon the wall he pulte, 1931 Anon his baner β ‖ one þe wall he pult D, he vnfolde A, he dyde vnfolde H, one þe walle was fechid full righte B.
Many a Gryffon it byhulte. 1932 Griffons and Ffrensh A, That ys enemys H, Monesir Griffoune B ‖ yt beheld D, hit byholte A, myght beholde H, it gerte there be pighte B.
As greyhoundes stryken out of lese 1933 As grew∣hounde B, Right as g. A, Ryght as grehowndes H, Os þe Gre∣founs D ‖ strekede owte BD, stryked oute A, passen H ‖ of lees A, of lesse H, of þe l. B.
Kynge Rycharde threste amonge the prese. 1933 und 1934 stehen in β zwischen 1940 und 1941. 1934 K.] f. D ‖ passed emange B, prekyd into D, priked thoughoute A, pryked þurgh H ‖ prees A, presse H.
Seuen chaynes with his good swerde D zwischen 1934 und 1935: Wiþ a swerd oone hond jdrawe | Many a Grefone he hath jslawe. 1935 And s. BH ‖ chynes B ‖ w. h. brod s. D, w. h. s. BEH, Kyng Richarde A.
Our kynge forcarfe a mydwarde, 1936 O. k. smate insonder B, R . . . a twoo E, Ric. smot D, He cutte a too H, Wiþ his swerde a twoo karf A ‖ a] in þe DB, on the H, the A, f. E ‖ mydwerde B.
That were drawen for grete doute 1937 weren δ ‖ draw E β, d. þere B ‖ for d. B.
Within the gates and without. 1938 ȝatis BD, yate β.
Porcules and gates vp he wan, 1939 Portecules E, Portecoleys H, Portcolys A, Porte∣colys B, Porcolys D ‖ yates β, ȝate D, barreres B.
And lette come in euery man. 1940 And yaf hem Goddes cours vppon her pan A, And yaffe Goddes curs to ther panne H; lete B ‖ in comyn D ‖ ilke a man D, alle his mene B.
Men myght se by strete and lane 1941 þane myghte mene see B, Ther myght men see A, þe nyth men myth se D ‖ be st. D, bothe st. B ‖ a.] or A.
Frensshe and Gryffons casche here bane. 1942 Ffranche men a. G. B, F. G. β, þe F . . . (unleserlich) E ‖ gaue b. W, tholed schame B, to take schame H, her schame A.
Some to hous ran in haste, 1943 Sume D, Many A, Meny H, And s. W ‖ to h. ronnyn D, jn to howsses þane rane B, ranne to howse H, to hors ran W ‖ fast δ, full faste B.
Dores and wyndowes barred faste. 1944 And d. B, And shette d. β ‖ wyndose B, wyndewes A, wyndounys D ‖ b. in haste B, schettyn f. D, fast β:

The Englissh brake them vp with levours, 1945 Bot þe Y. mene B, Oure Englissh A, Englysche menne H, And euer men W ‖ bare them vp W, hem brostyn D, rane to B, f. β ‖ wiþ grete levours A, wiþ leuauns D.
And slewe them with grete vygours. 1946 A. slowin hem D, A. brake þame vp B, Brake hem vpp H, Breke hem vp A ‖ viours B, vemauns D.
All that they founde ayenst them stande, 1947 And alle þat B ‖ þei fondyn D, hir f. A, gan B ‖ agayne þame st. B, byfore hem stonde β, and wolde stonde D, . . . stonde (das andere unleserlich) E.
Passed thorough dethes hande. 1948 All hij passed A, Tokyn here deth D, Adowne H ‖ throw here honde D, thorowe þe dynt of hande B, þouȝth Goddes sonde A, þey leyde on the sonde H.
They brake cofers, and toke tresours, 1949 brokyn D, breken β ‖ towke H, takyn D ‖ tresoure BDβ.
Golde, and syluer, and couertours, 1950 G. s. β ‖ couertoure BD, . . . re E, couerture H, countours W.
Jeweles, stones, and spycery, 1951 Fful fyne st. B, Rynges and brochis D.
All that they founde in tresoury. 1951 und 1952 fehlen β. 1952 And alle BD ‖ foundyn D, fande B ‖ tresory B.
There was none of Englysshe blode 1953 nas A ‖ nane B ‖ of the Y. b. B, of oure E. b. β.
That he ne had as moche gode 1954 Bot þat ne he h. B ‖ os D, so H, ther so A, als so B ‖ mekill BD, mych A.
As they wolde drawe or bere 1955 Os þ. woldyn D, As he myght β, Als þat þay myghte B ‖ drawghe H, bothe d. B ‖ or] and Bβ.
To shyppe or to pauylyons, i swere. 1956 To chep D ‖ or pauylon D, and paui∣loun β, and pauylyoune B ‖ i ȝow s. BD, y þe swore H, also i swere A.
And euer cryed Kynge Rycharde: 1957 oure K. R. β.
"Slee downe righte the Frensshe cowarde, 1958 Sla B ‖ d.] adowne H ‖ rightes thes A, þese H, euery W ‖ Franche u. ö. B ‖ mosardes β.
And ken them in batayl 1959 A. kythes thaym B, A. kyl we hem D ‖ in ȝoure b. B, in oure b. D, in bataylles W.
That ye haue no tayl." 1959 und 1960 fehlen B. 1960 ȝe ne haue B, we ne hauyn D ‖ no tayles W, no manere of t. B, neuer no t. D.
The Kynge of Fraunce came pryckynge 1961 Ther come the K. of F. A, Ther come forþe þe Frensche kyng H ‖ com prikynge D, com þan prikynge B, þe kyng A, f. H.
Ayenst Rycharde our kynge, 1962 Ageyne R. D, Vnto R. B β ‖ oure noble k. B, oure nobil k. D, fast prykyng H.
And fell on knees downe of his hors, 1963 done on kneys D.
And bad mercy, for Goddes corps; 1963 und 1964 fehlen β. 1964 cryed m. B, bad hym sesyn D ‖ f. G. cros D B.
For the crowne, and for the loue 1965 And f. þe c. BD, And bade him cese A, And badde him sese H ‖ a. þe l. D, for Goddes l. β.

Therfore Ric. wiþout distaunce
Sent after þe kyng of Ffraunce.
He soiourned in Acres-citee
Þat tyme, as y telle it þee.
He com to Ric. wiþout faile,
And he him asked consaile,
Ȝif he wolde wiþoute essoyne,

No more but ten ȝere. 7206 Noghte bot allanly t. B.
Syþþe he was schot, allas, 7207 Sythyn was he slayne wiþ schotte a. B.
In Castel Gaylard, þer he was. 7208 At the C.-Galyarde where he B.
Þus endyd Rychard oure kyng; 7209 And th. endys þe romaunce of R. B.
God geue vs alle good endyng, 7210 And G. grante B.
And hys soule reste and roo,
And oure soules whenne we come þertoo! 7211 und 7212 nicht in B.

DIV1.P: W A haben an Stelle von v. 7203 ff. folgende Schlußverse:

L.HI: Thus Kynge Rycharde, þe doughty man,
Peas made with the Sowdan;
L.NOTE: 7204 M. pes bitwene hym and the S.A.

L.HI: And syth he came, j vnderstonde,
The waye towarde Englonde;
And thorugh treason was shotte, alas,
L.NOTE: 7207 A. hamward w. shoten allas A.

L.HI: At castell Gaylarde, there he was.
The Duke of Estryche in the castell
With his hoost was dyght full well.
Rycharde thought there to abyde;
The weder was hote in somers tyde,
At Gaylarde vnder the castell
He wende he myght haue keled hym well.
His helme he abbated thare,
And made his vysage all bare.
A spye there was in the castell,
That espyed Rycharde ryght well,
And toke an arblaste swythe stronge,
And a quarell that was well longe,
And smote Kynge Rycharde in tene,
In the heed without wene.
L.NOTE: Statt 7215-7222 A, f. 275e: And bysegid the Castel Gailard byside Lemones, and strongly assailed hit, so that the vij kln of Aprill, as the kynge went aboute the castell to avise hit, vnarmed, a knyght cleped Peris Besile sodenly bende his arblast vppon the walles, and haply with a gayne smot the kyng in the lifte shuldre, and made dedly wounde.

L.HI: Rycharde let his helme downe fall,
L.NOTE: 7223 Kyng R. tho let his men calle A.

L.HI: And badde his men dyght them all,
And swore by the see and the sonne
Tyll the castell were jwonne,
Ne sholde neyther mete ne drynke
Neuer into his body synke.
He set vp Robynet that tyde
Upon the castelles syde.
And on that other halfe of the toune
He set vp the Mategryffone.
L.NOTE: 7232 He let arere the Maudegriffoune A.

L.HI: To the castell he threwe stones,
L.NOTE: 7233 And to A ‖ he] hij A.

L.HI: And brake the walles for the nones;
And so within a lytell tyde
Into the castel they gan ryde,
And slewe before and behynde
All tho that they myght ayenst them fynde;
L.NOTE: 7238 That he m. tofore hym f. A.

L.HI: And euer was the quarell by the lede
L.NOTE: 7239 w.] byleued A ‖ by the l.] f. A.

L.HI: Stycked styll in Rychardes hede;
L.NOTE: 7240 Stikynge faste in his sheldere A.

L.HI: And whan it was drawen out,
L.NOTE: Statt 7241 bis Schluß A, f. 275e: And when the kyng sey that he was in perile of deth, he let of sende iij abbotes of Cisteaux ordre, that is of grey...

L.HI: He dyed soone without doute;

LG.L: And he commaunded in all thynge

L.HI: To his fader men sholde hym brynge;
That they ne let, for nesshe ne harde,
Tyll he were at the Font Euerarde.
At Font Euerarte wytterly
His bones lye his fader by:
Kynge Harry forsothe he hyght,
All Englonde he helde to ryght.
Kyng Rycharde was a conquerour,
God gyue his soule moche honour.
No more of hym in Englysshe is wrought,
But Jhesu that vs dere bought
Graunte his soule rest and ro,
And ours whan it cometh therto;
And that it may so be,
Saye all Amen for charyte!
